The wheels are plenty strong and they'll run in a straight line for sure. The big thing that will affect them is flex of your ship. Struts are your best friend. For example here is my Spaceship 2 using two small adjustable gear on the noses. And two up scaled medium gear for the main / tail gear on a 50t plane. As you can see it will take off in a straight line (it brakes straight as well) But you need to eliminate all the flex you can. I used around 12 B9 invisible struts to make this work.

One issue I can see right away is the wheels are very close together. Think of a dragster, long wheelbase to stabilize direction of travel at high speeds. Try moving the nose gear farther forward. Also if you can I would shorten them as well. That will further help stabilize the plane on take off.

It is also very high. Real planes are made to sit as low as possible without it hitting the ground at any point.

Might have already been covered...but is there any possibility of future versions having gear that fold horizontally, similar to how gear work on airliners, small jets, and some military aircraft. Have them able to fold into the wing perpendicular to the longitudinal axis of the aircraft?

Might have already been covered...but is there any possibility of future versions having gear that fold horizontally, similar to how gear work on airliners, small jets, and some military aircraft. Have them able to fold into the wing perpendicular to the longitudinal axis of the aircraft?

This style of gear folding (folding laterally inwards or outwards, rotating gear legs along the roll axis of the aircraft) was common circa WWII, I know, for smaller aircraft. The mechanism is simpler as you don't need to fold the wheels to fit them in a narrow wing - just folding the gear leg up rotates the wheel horizontal. This allowed many craft to have far wider gear placements that they otherwise would have.
